en.value: I have a job interview tomorrow!
Preparing for a job application
Job hunting
In this unit, we are going to start looking at the process of finding a job. On the following screens you will find useful expressions and tips to talk about your job search.
Here's a tip!
James told me you are looking for a job in Sweden, are you moving there?
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
James told me you are [k]looking[/k] [k]for[/k] a job in Sweden.
look
to
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.

You will often hear expressions like job hunting, job seeking or job searching, which all mean "trying to find a job" and are all interchangeable. We can use them both as nouns and as verbs. Have a look at the examples below.
Verb: Job searching is exhausting!
Noun: Good luck with the job hunting.
I finally found a job after two months of job hunting!
"Job hunting" means the same as "job seeking".
Job searching is exhausting!
True or false?
I finally found a job after two months of job [k]hunting[/k]!
hunter
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.

These days, people mainly look for jobs online, on job websites. On these websites, you can find job adverts and apply for jobs. Usually you will send your CV and a cover letter. In American English, a CV is usually called a resume. A resume or CV is a short description of your qualifications and experience.
I was looking online yesterday, and I saw an interesting advert.
I need to apply before midnight, otherwise it's too late.
If you want to apply for a job, you need to...
send your CV / resume.
find a job.
send a job advert.
I was looking online yesterday, and I saw an interesting [k]advert[/k].
cover
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
I need to [k]a[/k][k]p[/k][k]p[/k][k]l[/k][k]y[/k] before midnight.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
Instead of using the verb "to apply" you can also say "to send an application".
Nina sent an application to the UN. She wants to work there as an interpreter.
Click on the words that mean "applied"
Nina [h]sent[/h] [h]an[/h] [h]application[/h] to the UN, she wants to work there as an interpreter.
CV
cover letter
job advert
You'll probably see more job adverts tomorrow.
Please send your CV as well as a cover letter.
Match the pairs of words / phrases.
Before sending an application, it is a good idea to update your CV or your online profile to make sure they include all the relevant information.
Have you updated your CV recently?
What should you update before sending an application? Click on the words.
advert [h]CV[/h] [h]profile[/h] job
[k]I[/k] [k]am[/k] [k]going[/k] [k]to[/k] [k]update[/k] [k]my[/k] [k]CV[/k] [k]today[/k].
Select the words in the correct order.

At the end of the job hunting process, probably after an interview, you will receive a job offer if you are successful. We also use the phrase to offer someone the job. You can either accept or decline a job offer.
They should offer him the job, he has a great CV and did well in the interview.
They should [k]offer him[/k] the job, he has a great CV and did well in the interview.
offer he
Click on the sentence with the same meaning as the audio.
Jamie has a new job.
Jamie declined the job offer.
Jamie is sending an application.
job offer
Pedro has rejected the job offer.
job hunting
online profile
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Did you know Nina sent an [k]application[/k] to the UN? Apparently she wants to work there as an interpreter.
Yes, she told me! I really think they will [k]offer[/k] her the job, she has a great resume!
Yeah, I hope so, that would be amazing!
And she told me you are [k]looking for[/k] a job in Sweden. Do you want to move there?
Yeah, I want to move in May. Actually, I was [k]looking online[/k] yesterday and I found a really interesting advert!
Cool! Have you applied yet?
No, I need to [k]update[/k] my CV first, and I have to [k]apply[/k] before midnight tonight, otherwise it's too late.
Well, good luck with your [k]job hunting[/k], I hope you get the job!
Thank you!
Sonia
Alexander
Which sentence describes what is happening in the dialogue?
Nina is job hunting.
Nina found a job at the UN.
Nina has had a job offer.
Listen to the dialogue. Is this statement true?
Sonia has found a job in Sweden.
Sonia is looking for a job in Sweden.
Before applying Sonia needs to...
add information to her CV.
start job hunting online.
respond to the advert.
"CV" and "resume" have the same meaning.
Nina [k]sent[/k] an [k]application[/k] to the UN.
send
CV
I was [k]looking online[/k] yesterday, and I saw an interesting advert.
Complete the sentence by writing in the box.
Write a synonym of "job searching"
Job [k]hunting|seeking[/k] is exhausting!
Choose the word that means: to add relevant info
I am going to [k]update[/k] my CV later today.
create
Jamie accepted the [k]job offer[/k].
When you apply for a job you need to send your [k]CV|resume[/k].
a short description of your education and work experience.
Fill in the gap using the hint.
I [k]applied[/k] for a job in Milan last week.
application
How did you find your current job? / How will you find your next job?

I found my current job after months of job hunting. After updating my CV, I found an advert online and sent an application. My skills and experience suited the role perfectly, and I think I made a good impression at the interview, because I was offered the job on the same day.
The Interview

"Before getting a job you usually have an interview. In this unit, we’ll learn some useful phrases that you might hear or say in a job interview. First impression is important! You might make a good impression, but you might make a bad impression."
I hope I made a good impression in my interview!
Memorise the word(s).
This means to "have a positive effect" on someone.
To make a bad impression
This means to "have a negative effect" on someone.
I hope I made a good [k]impression[/k] in my interview!
expression

Employers interview various candidates before choosing the best and offering them the job. When talking about a job vacancy you will also hear the terms position and role. Have a look at the sentences below.
I think I am a good candidate for that role.
You need a degree in foreign languages to apply for this position.
We offered him the job. He was definitely the best candidate.
Did you notice? We can use the word interview both as a verb and as a noun! Here are some examples.
Noun: I have an interview tomorrow at 10 a.m.
Verb: My manager interviewed three candidates for the role.
In this sentence "interview" is used as a noun.
My manager interviewed three candidates for the role.
In this sentence "interview" is used as a verb.
A candidate is...
someone who has applied for a job.
a new employee in a company.
someone who made a bad impression.
candidate [h]role[/h] impression [h]position[/h] degree
Click on the synonyms of "job vacancy" you learned.
So what makes a good candidate? Usually it is his/her skills, qualifications and experience. We can also say that someone is a good / bad fit for a position.
Laura's skills and qualifications are perfect for this role.
Simon doesn't think she would be a good fit for the position.
This means Laura is a good fit for the position.
Laura's skills and qualifications are perfect for this role.
Simon doesn't think she is a [k]good[/k] [k]fit[/k] for the position.
badly
feet
Someone's skills and qualifications come from...
their experience and studies.
their first impression.
their application.
You need to have at least three years' experience to apply for this job.
You need to have at least three years' [k]e[/k][k]x[/k][k]p[/k][k]e[/k][k]r[/k][k]i[/k][k]e[/k][k]n[/k][k]c[/k]e to apply for this job.
skills
experience
impression
Next, we’ll look at some questions that you sometimes hear in an interview. If you want to practise, you can try answering each question before going to the next screen.
What would you say are your strengths, and what are your weaknesses?
Click on the "strengths" in the following sentences.
Robert is very [h]organised[/h].
Annette is quite impatient. However, she is [h]flexible[/h] and [h]driven[/h].
Can you provide any references?
A "reference" is a recommendation from a person who knows you.
I included two references in my CV.
Kelly isn't scared to go into battle.
strength
weakness
experience
a positive quality in a person
a negative trait in a person
the knowledge acquired through other jobs
What would you say are your [k]strengths[/k], and what are your weaknesses?
I am very organised and [k]driven[/k]. Sometimes I can get a little [k]impatient[/k], but I am working on that.
Ok, thank you. We read on your CV that you worked for the [k]company[/k] Lea Mobile. Can you provide any [k]references[/k]?
Yes, of course. I will send you the details of my [k]manager[/k], Tom.
That would be great, thank you. So, Eric, why do you think you are the right [k]candidate[/k] for this role?
I think I'm a [k]good fit[/k] for the company, as I have worked in similar environments before, and I have a [k]strong passion[/k] and drive for what I do.
Thank you, Eric. We believe you are a good candidate and your [k]skills[/k] and experience are relevant to the [k]role[/k]. We will let you know by the end of the week.
Ok, thank you very much. I look forward to hearing from you.
Interviewer
Eric
Patience is Eric’s strength.
Eric can sometimes get impatient.
Eric...
thinks his experience is relevant to the role.
says he isn't a good fit for the company.
doesn't have any experience in similar environments.
Eric made a good impression in the interview.
What are your [k]strengths[/k] and your [k]weaknesses[/k]?
strength
weak
Laura's [k]skills[/k] and qualifications are perfect for this role.
skill
You are a good candidate if...
you have relevant skills and qualifications.
you don't have any experience.
you make a bad impression.
Can you provide any [k]references[/k]?
Complete the sentence using the information in the box.
I think I am a good [k]candidate[/k] for that role.
interview
Simon doesn't think she would be a [k]good fit[/k] for the position.
You need a degree in foreign languages to apply for this [k]position|job[/k].
Write a synonym of "role"
We offered him the job. He was definitely the [k]best[/k] candidate.
worst
I hope I made a good impression in my [k]interview[/k]!
Type the word that means "negative traits in a person".
What would you say are your strengths, and what are your [k]weaknesses[/k]?
Indirect Speech

When we want to tell someone about a previous conversation, there are two ways to do this: using direct or indirect speech. In direct speech (example 1), we give the exact words. Indirect speech (example 2) focuses more on the content, not on the exact words.
Direct speech: She said "I will let you know by the end of the week".
Indirect speech: She said that she would let me know by the end of the week.
Click on the sentence with indirect speech.
He told me that I could start on Monday.
I said "You don't have the right experience."
She said "I will let you know by Friday".
Read the sentence. Who has got the job? Nick or Emma?
[k]Nick[/k]
Nick: Emma told me I'd got the job!
We can use the word "that" when we use indirect speech. In this context, it is a conjunction.
I told her that I had lots of experience in finance.
He said that I was perfect for the role.
We told him that he got the job.
[k]I told her[/k] [k]that[/k] [k]I have lots of experience in finance[/k][k].[/k]
[k]He said[/k] [k]that[/k] [k]I was perfect for the job[/k][k].[/k]
We often use verbs like "to say" and "to tell" to introduce indirect speech. This is called the reporting verb. With the verb "to tell" we need an indirect object.
She said that the interview went well.
We told her that she'd got the job.
Select the reporting verb in each sentence.
I [h]said[/h] that he didn't have the right experience.
He [h]told[/h] me that I was perfect for the job!
This sentence contains indirect speech.
He said that he had lots of experience in recruitment.
Did you know? It's very common to omit the word "that", particularly in spoken English. Look at the examples below. Both are correct and both have the same meaning.
I told her that I had lots of experience in finance.
I told her I had lots of experience in finance.
He told me I didn't have the right experience.
Complete the two sentences.
I said
I said that
"You don't have the right experience."
he didn't have the right experience.
Complete the two sentences.
You told me
You told me that
"The interview went quite well".
the interview had gone quite well.

When we use indirect speech, we often change parts of the sentence. Personal pronouns and verb conjugations often need to change. 

Did you notice? If the reporting verb is in a past tense, we sometimes change the tense in the indirect speech as well. This is not obligatory, but it's useful to know. We'll learn how the tense changes on the following screens.
Direct speech: I have lots of experience in finance.
Indirect speech: She told me that she has / had lots of experience in finance.
The tense always stays the same between direct and indirect speech.
I told her that I had lots of experience in finance.
The tense sometimes changes in indirect speech when the reporting verb is in a past tense.
In this table, you can see how tenses change between direct speech and indirect speech. We haven't learned all of these tenses yet, but don't worry. For now, we'll focus on the tenses that we know.
Phrase in direct speech
Phrase in indirect speech
Present simple
Past simple
Present continuous
Past continuous
Past simple
Past perfect
Present perfect
Past perfect
Past continuous
Past perfect continuous
Future
Present conditional

Here's an example. The reporting verb is "told" and it is in the past simple tense. In the first sentence, the direct speech is in the present tense. In the second sentence, the indirect speech can be in the present simple or the past simple tense.
Direct speech: He told me "You are perfect for the job!"
Indirect speech: He told me that I was perfect for the job! / He told me that I'm perfect for the job.
Direct speech
Indirect speech
Present simple
Present simple / Past simple
Present simple / Past continuous
Present simple / Past perfect
Past simple
Past simple / Past perfect
Past simple / Present simple
Past simple / Past continuous
Future
Future / Present conditional
Future / Present simple
Future / Present continuous
Some verbs follow different patterns. Here is a table to show you how some verbs change (or stay the same!) in indirect speech.
Verb in direct speech
Verb in indirect speech
will
would
can
could
could
could
would
would
should
should
must
must
He said that he [k]would email[/k] me before Wednesday.
is emailing
I said that we [k]can't[/k] offer him the job.
doesn't
[k]You[/k] [k]told[/k] [k]me[/k] [k]that[/k] [k]the interview[/k] [k]went[/k] [k]quite well.[/k]
[k]She[/k] [k]said[/k] [k]he[/k] [k]was[/k] [k]a great fit[/k] [k]for the role.[/k]
James told me [k]you were looking[/k] for a job in Sweden.
you look
Complete the sentence using the past continuous tense.
They said that they [k]were interviewing|are interviewing[/k] a few people for the position.
"We are interviewing a few people for the position", they said.
[k]I told[/k] [k]them[/k] [k]that[/k] [k]I[/k] [k]could[/k] [k]start[/k] [k]on Monday.[/k]
Complete the sentence using the past simple tense.
He told me that [k]I was|I am|I'm[/k] a great fit for the team.
"You are a great fit for the team", he said.
Rewrite the sentence below using indirect speech.
He told me that [k]he would email me before Wednesday|he will email me before Wednesday|he'll email me before Wednesday[/k].
"I will email you before Wednesday."
They told me that my skills and qualifications [k]were[/k] perfect for the role.
was
Rewrite the sentence below using indirect speech.
He told me that [k]he had lots of experience|he has lots of experience[/k] in recruitment.
"I have lots of experience in recruitment", he said.
[k]You[/k] [k]said[/k] [k]that[/k] [k]he[/k] [k]made[/k] [k]a good impression[/k] [k]in the interview.[/k]
He said [k]he could provide references|that he could provide references|he can provide references|that he can provide references[/k].
"I can provide references".
I told her that [k]she didn't have the right experience|she doesn't have the right experience[/k].
"You don't have the right experience."
